dialogue_history.content:
Analyze this financial news and estimate stock price movement probabilities.
Company: Apple Inc. (AAPL)
News Headline: Prediction: This Will Be Wall Street's First $5 Trillion Company -- and It's Not Nvidia
News Content: Change is perhaps the only certainty on Wall Street. Due to factors such as innovation, competition, mergers and acquisitions, bankruptcies, and legal judgments, the puzzle pieces that make up the largest publicly traded companies are constantly in flux.

When 2004 came to a close, ExxonMobil was the largest publicly traded company in the S&P 500, with Citigroup and General Electric also in the top 10. Today, Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) is the only member of the end-of-2004 top 10 that's still among America's largest publicly traded companies.Image source: Getty Images.

Since the midpoint of 2023, we've witnessed Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), Microsoft, and semiconductor colossus Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) all surpass the $3 trillion valuation plateau. Although Nvidia would seem like the surest bet to reach the psychologically important $5 trillion level given the rise of artificial intelligence (AI), a dark-horse candidate may have the clearest path to become Wall Street's first $5 trillion company.

Nvidia is battling against history, which has a flawless track record

On one hand, there's no denying that Nvidia has enjoyed a textbook operating expansion. The company's Hopper (H100) graphics processing units (GPUs) and successor Blackwell chips have been the preferred options for businesses wanting to run generative AI solutions and train large language models in their high-compute data centers.

With demand for GPUs overwhelming supply, Nvidia has been able to command $30,000 to $40,000 for its Hopper chip, which is up to four times as much as Advanced Micro Devices has charged customers for its Instinct MI300X GPU. Having otherworldly pricing power helped to push Nvidia's gross margin to as high as 78.4% last year.

While the long-term outlook for AI remains encouraging and this technology has real-world applications in most industries around the globe, Nvidia's chances of becoming Wall Street's first $5 trillion company are likely going to be thwarted by history.

Roughly three decades ago, the internet began going mainstream and offered businesses a new way to connect with potential customers. Though the internet did, eventually, alter the growth trajectory for corporate America is a positive way, it took years before businesses really understood how to harness these new sales and marketing channels.

Including the internet, every game-changing technology or innovation for 30 years has navigated its way through an early stage bubble. In simpler terms, investors have consistently overestimated how quickly a new technology/innovation would be adopted or gain widespread utility. With most companies lacking clear game plans as to how they'll maximize the return on their AI investments, it sets artificial intelligence up to be the next in a long line of bubbles.

Story Continues

Since no company has benefited more directly from the AI revolution than Nvidia, the logical expectation is that its stock would be hit the hardest. Historic precedent makes it unlikely that Nvidia ascends to a $5 trillion valuation first.Image source: Amazon.

This dark-horse candidate has a clear path to become America's largest public company

If history were to rhyme and the AI bubble bursts, it would also be bad news for Microsoft, which has been investing heavily in an artificial intelligence-driven future. Although Microsoft's operating cash flow isn't as overwhelmingly reliant on AI as Nvidia, being the first to reach a $5 trillion valuation would be a stretch.

The same can be said for Wall Street's other $3 trillion public company, Apple. Though Apple's Services segment continues to grow by a double-digit percentage, its physical device sales, including iPhone, have stagnated for two years. Apple stock is already trading at one of its priciest valuations in a decade, which leaves little room for its valuation to rise by another $1.4 trillion.

The "Magnificent Seven" component that appears to have the clearest path to a $5 trillion market cap is e-commerce juggernaut Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN).

When most consumers and investors hear the Amazon name, they think of its dominant online marketplace. Last February, eMarketer estimated that Amazon would account for just over 40% of U.S. online retail sales in 2024. While this online retail platform has been the face of Amazon for nearly three decades, e-commerce plays a minimal role in terms of cash flow generation and operating income.

The lion's share of Amazon's growth potential (specifically growth in cash flow) originates from its ancillary operating segments, with Amazon Web Services (AWS) at the front of the pack.

Based on data from tech-analysis firm Canalys, AWS is the world's leading cloud infrastructure service platform, with an estimated 33% share of total cloud spending during the third quarter of 2024. For context, Amazon's share of spending among cloud-service providers is more than Microsoft's Azure and Alphabet's Google Cloud, combined — and these are the No's 2 and 3 in global cloud-service spending.

Even though AI has played a role in AWS's growth, enterprise spending on cloud services was growing at a steady double-digit pace long before AI became the hottest thing since sliced bread on Wall Street. With enterprise cloud-service spending still in its relatively early stages of expansion, Amazon can expect substantially higher margins from this segment to meaningfully boost its cash flow.

Beyond AWS, Amazon's advertising services and subscription services (e.g., Prime) segments are also respectively growing by double digits. Amazon's push into exclusive sporting events (Thursday Night Football and NBA streaming packages) should improve demand for advertising, as well as support its subscription pricing power.

The key point is that, unlike Microsoft and Nvidia, Amazon wouldn't be dragged down by the AI bubble bursting thanks to its abundance of other catalysts.

Lastly, Amazon remains historically inexpensive. Throughout the 2010s, investors willingly paid 23 to 37 times year-end cash flow to own shares of the company. But as of the closing bell on Jan. 10, Amazon's shares are valued at just 13.5 times consensus cash flow for 2026. If Amazon were to reach the median year-end multiple to cash flow it traded at consistently from 2010 through 2019, it would become Wall Street's first $5 trillion company.

Don’t miss this second chance at a potentially lucrative opportunity

Ever feel like you missed the boat in buying the most successful stocks? Then you’ll want to hear this.

On rare occasions, our expert team of analysts issues a “Double Down” stock recommendation for companies that they think are about to pop. If you’re worried you’ve already missed your chance to invest, now is the best time to buy before it’s too late. And the numbers speak for themselves:

Nvidia: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2009, you’d have $352,417!* Apple: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2008, you’d have $44,855!* Netflix: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2004, you’d have $451,759!*

Right now, we’re issuing “Double Down” alerts for three incredible companies, and there may not be another chance like this anytime soon.

See 3 “Double Down” stocks »

*Stock Advisor returns as of January 13, 2025

Citigroup is an advertising partner of Motley Fool Money. Suzanne Frey, an executive at Alphabet, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. John Mackey, former CEO of Whole Foods Market, an Amazon subsidiary, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. Sean Williams has positions in Alphabet and Amazon. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Advanced Micro Devices, Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, and Nvidia. The Motley Fool recommends GE Aerospace and recommends the following options: long January 2026 $395 calls on Microsoft and short January 2026 $405 calls on Microsoft. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.

Prediction: This Will Be Wall Street's First $5 Trillion Company -- and It's Not Nvidia was originally published by The Motley Fool

View Comments

Next I will provide you some predictions of stock price movement probabilities and the corresponding analysis by others in the previous rounds.
Note that others' predictions may indicate that they have some other information about the stock price. A high prediction may indicate that they have some positive information about the stock, while a low prediction may indicate that they have some megative information about the stock.
Also note that there are multiple rounds of precitions, demonstrating the trend of others' beliefs.
Please take these information into consideration when prediction the stock price movement probabilities.
Previous predictions:
Round: 0
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.6, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.4, Reasoning: The news headline relates to luxury stocks, and while Apple Inc. is not exclusively a luxury brand, its products are often priced at a premium. The discussion around luxury stocks might indicate positive sentiment in high-end consumer spending, which could indirectly benefit Apple. However, the headline does not provide direct information about Apple and leaves room for uncertainty concerning its specific impact on AAPL stock. Hence, there is a moderate probability of the stock price rising, but also some chance of it falling depending on broader market reactions to luxury spending trends.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.4, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.6, Reasoning: The news presents a mixed outlook for Apple (AAPL). Positively, Apple ranks 2nd on the list of important AI news and ratings and continues to grow strongly in non-core markets like Latin America. However, the headline suggests a struggle for Apple to regain market share. The iPhone maker has lost market share in the final quarter and faces challenges due to the lack of AI availability in China, which has impacted performance in that region, and a mixed response to the iPhone 16 series due to limited availability of Apple Intelligence. Additionally, competitors in China are gaining strength. The article also highlights governmental regulations impacting AI chip exports, which could indirectly affect Apple's AI development and market position, though those are longer term impacts. The article suggests, the US government is prioritizing AI leadership which could favor US companies, but the incoming administration of Donald Trump is expected to make significant changes that may affect AI innovation, with policy potentially moving towards more open AI development, which may or may not benefit Apple. Considering all these factors, there is a slightly higher probability of a stock price fall than rise.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The article focuses on the potential for Amazon (AMZN) to become the first $5 trillion company, arguing against Nvidia and downplaying Apple's prospects.  The argument rests on several points: 1) The potential bursting of the AI bubble will negatively impact Nvidia and Microsoft, which are heavily invested in AI. 2) While Apple is strong, its valuation is already high, leaving little room for the massive growth needed to hit $5 trillion. 3) Amazon's diverse revenue streams, particularly AWS's dominant position in the cloud computing market,  combined with its relatively inexpensive valuation compared to its historical multiples, position it for substantial future growth.  The article is bullish on Amazon and implicitly bearish on Apple and Nvidia. However, the prediction is speculative and based on macroeconomic assumptions and historical analogies, not on specific financial details about Apple.  The impact on Apple's stock price from this news is therefore likely to be muted.  While the article suggests that Apple is less likely to reach a $5 trillion valuation than Amazon, it doesn't provide specific reasons why Apple's stock price should rise or fall directly as a result of the opinion piece.  The possibility of a market reaction to the overall sentiment of the article against the AI market is possible, but I'm assuming the impact on AAPL will be small.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The news article highlights Apple's strong competitive advantages, including its innovation, brand loyalty, and significant market share in consumer electronics and services. It also mentions Apple's expansion into AI and its growing services revenue, which are seen as new growth opportunities. The article acknowledges that while Apple may not offer the same explosive growth as newer companies, its established market dominance and financial strength position it well for steady future gains. Given the positive tone of the article and the emphasis on Apple's strengths and growth potential, the stock is likely to be viewed favorably by investors.
Model: meta-llama/llama-4-scout, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.05, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.05, Reasoning: The news headline 'Investing in Luxury Stocks' does not directly mention Apple Inc. (AAPL) or provide specific information about the company's performance, products, or financials. Luxury stocks are often associated with high-end brands, and while Apple is a luxury tech brand, the headline lacks specificity. As a result, it's unlikely to have a significant direct impact on Apple's stock price. Therefore, I estimate that the probability of the stock price rising due to this news is low, and the probability of it falling is also low, with a slight bias towards the stock price remaining stable or being influenced by other market factors.
Model: meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The article discusses Apple's strong competitive advantage, earnings growth, and innovative products, which have contributed to its position as the world's largest company. The company's expansion into services revenue and AI could power a new phase of growth. While the article suggests that Apple may not deliver the same growth as younger companies, its dominance and strong moat make it a compelling buy for most investors. Based on this analysis, the probability of the stock price rising is higher than falling.
Model: qwen/qwen-turbo, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The financial news highlights a prediction that the first $5 trillion company on Wall Street will not be Nvidia but might be Amazon instead. The article suggests Amazon has strong ancillary operating segments, including AWS, which provides substantial growth potential beyond AI. Additionally, Amazon is described as historically inexpensive compared to its past multiples, suggesting room for valuation increase. These factors suggest positive developments for Amazon which might influence investors favorably.


Now give your prediction about the probability of the stock price of the relevant company rising or falling. Format your response in JSON format and include the following information as follows: 
{ 
"reasoning": "[Summarize your analysis and reasoning process here]", 
"company_name": "[Company Name indicating the name of the company]", 
"company_symbol": "[Company Symbol indicating the stock symbol of the company]", 
"news_headline": "[News Headline indicating the provided financial news headline]", 
"probability_of_stock_price_rise": [The estimated probability (a number between 0 and 1) that the stock price will rise due to this news], 
"probability_of_stock_price_fall": [The estimated probability (a number between 0 and 1) that the stock price will fall due to this news], 
} 
Do not generate output that isn't in properly formatted JSON.

```json
{
  "reasoning": "The article focuses on Amazon's potential to become the first $5 trillion company, implicitly suggesting that Apple's chances are lower.  While the article highlights Apple's strengths and growth in services, it also points out its high valuation, leaving limited room for significant further growth.  The prediction that an AI bubble might burst is negative for AI-heavy companies like Nvidia and Microsoft, but the impact on Apple is less direct, given its diversified revenue streams.  Previous predictions are mixed, with probabilities of a price rise ranging from 0.05 to 0.7. Considering the article's relatively neutral stance on Apple and the diverse opinions in the previous round,  a neutral stance seems most appropriate. The likelihood of a significant price movement based solely on this article appears low. The relatively high valuation of Apple already factors in much of its positive outlook.",
  "company_name": "Apple Inc.",
  "company_symbol": "AAPL",
  "news_headline": "Prediction: This Will Be Wall Street's First $5 Trillion Company -- and It's Not Nvidia",
  "probability_of_stock_price_rise": 0.45,
  "probability_of_stock_price_fall": 0.45
}
```
